name: Environmental Problems Quiz | Environmental Problems | 10 Questions

questions.text: The greatest danger facing most endangered species is which of these?
questions.explanation:
Habitat loss.

	Throughout the world, humans are burning, bulldozing, polluting and building on habitat.

questions.text: In 2012, which of the following is not listed as an endangered species under the U.S. Endangered Species Act (note, this is not limited to American animals)?
questions.explanation:
Bald eagle.

	The bald eagle's population has recovered well, and the species was delisted in 1999.

questions.text: The Bronx Zoo once had a picture frame covered by cloth. It was labelled 'The most dangerous species in the world'. If you removed the cover, what did you see?
questions.explanation:
A mirror.

	Showing the most dangerous species...humans.

questions.text: Which of the following substances is not biodegradable?
questions.explanation:
Styrofoam.

	Bacteria cannot break down styrofoam.

questions.text: What environmental problem is the result of chemical reactions in the atmosphere that involve sulfur?
questions.explanation:
Acid rain.

	Acid rain can turn lakes into sterile water where nothing can live.

questions.text: What chemicals have been banned in most of the world because of their role in destroying the ozone layer?
questions.explanation:
Chlorofluorocarbons.

	CFCs, as they are also known, were once widely used in aerosol propellants.

questions.text: Who wrote 'Silent Spring', the first book documenting many of the problems caused by pesticides?
questions.explanation:
Rachel Carson.

	Carson, who wrote in the 1960s, was one of the founders of the modern environmental movement.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a renewable resource?
questions.explanation:
Gold.

	Renewable resources are naturally replenished in a reasonable amount of time, nonrenewable ones are not.

questions.text: Which of the following practices produces the most organic water pollution?
questions.explanation:
Intensive livestock farming.

	Millions of gallons of manure and other animal wastes contaminate our waters yearly.

questions.text: 'Ecology' comes from the Greek words 'oikos' and 'logos'. What is the literal translation of them?
questions.explanation:
Household science.

	It is a word of fairly recent coinage. Logos means science and oikos means household, so ecology means the 'science of the household of nature'.
